commit.message: shims/scm: move to same path as Homebrew/brew.

Remove (almost) everything (#50678)

* cmd/help: tell people to run brew update.

* Remove (almost) all removable files.

update: fix hyphen counting (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@500f9eada854c1939bf9a0caf94085214c9399b0.
Counting the number of hyphens in a string cannot be done in a single
expression, thus split this and introduce another local variable.

update: remove stray comma (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@93e0f4f9465978460d411f27214e19ae3fc4d294.
README: clarify and improve human parseability (#50664)

CoreTap#install: fix clone target setting

When invoking `brew tap homebrew/core`, the input options will be like
`{ :clone_target => nil }`. This renders `Hash#merge` a dead operation.

It doesn't impact Homebrew itself, but could cause problem for
downstream projects Linuxbrew/Tigerbrew when they adopt core/formula
separation.

This commit is backported from
https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/commit/1b7e13df4f936dd318a23698b7b69bd2ca0e2487

nesc: assign minimum emacs version

On certain system(e.g. fe22f59), `brew update` will report
`Error: Specify a version for EmacsRequirement` before it could run
migration for brew 0.9.9.

This commit workaround this problem.

readme: clarify what's not in homebrew/brew

Closes #50661.

update: use --replace-all to set remote.origin.fetch

Otherwise, it will fail on users who have multiple entries on
remote.origin.fetch.

Update/split documentation.

Point to the new repositories instead.

various: add remote migration hack

Depends on what local revision users start with, there will be
several places which can be used to trigger remote migrations.
 * `tap_migrations`: some old system will load `tap_migrations` during
   `brew update`
 * `formula_revision`: old system whose revision is after
    c010cc8a8cadfe2e29f541570b70e62b6d735fb9 but before
    ac5707c37470c25583d8fb712bf5dc04ab91db4b will load `formula_revision`
    during `brew update`. This will help to solve #42553 on these
    systems
 * `update-reporter`: system since we implement bash update script.

Closes #50653.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>
test-bot: exclude Taps dir from root cleanup

test-bot: have --cleanup clean core repo as well as tested tap

Fixes #50651

test-bot: fix path in cleanup_before

We should remove PR lock files in the test tap rather than HOMEBREW_REPOSITORY.
pull: fix --legacy when pulling bottle from new repo

Revert "test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR"

This reverts commit 51e4e6490bda0d981afd1787a6392ab588b0601c. This did
not work as intended, as the `git` command is executed in the context of
the tap the current job operates on, never for Homebrew/homebrew itself.

test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR

Wipe everything from the Homebrew prefix except for the `Library/Taps`
directory to avoid having to refetch `homebrew/core` every time.

diagnostic: improve check for 'install_name_tool'

`install_name_tool` location depends on the location of the active developer
directory managed by `xcode-select`.

Closes #50509.

Will update to 0.9.9 when moving core code to new repo.
git: check homebrew/core existence before installing brewed git

fix brew tests

audit/test-bot/pull: fix for core/formula separation

All formulae are in taps now.

descriptions: update for core/formula separation

Update the description update logic, since now all formulae are in the taps.

update-report: update for core/formula separation

Update the report logic, since now all formulae are in the taps.

remove migrate_taps

We don't need to migrate the tapped formulae from symlink-based to
directory-based structure any more.

Instead, we add core tap install check for `brew update-report` which
will be invoked by `brew update`.

various: Homebrew/core is the core tap

Also make `Homebrew/homebrew` as an alias of this tap to keep
backward compatibility.

introduce `Homebrew/core` tap as new default core tap.

It will be auto installed whenever necessary.

gl2ps: prevent linking against X11's libglut.dylib

To avoid "accidentally" linking against X11's libglut.dylib when X11
happens to be installed, manually set

  GLUT_glut_LIBRARY=/System/Library/Frameworks/GLUT.framework

This allows the bottle build server to have X11 installed, but not end
up forcing us to add an X11 requirement to the formula.

Closes #50601.

open-scene-graph: work around an SDK 10.11 issue

This is not a true fix, as the actual problem is in the 10.11 SDK, that
is used in a non-standard way. That way, the compiler doesn't see the
headers as system headers and (rightfully) complains about them being
broken in C++11 mode.

See also <https://plus.google.com/+ThiagoMacieira/posts/2SmArLfeDZt>.

Since the failure is not OSG's fault, it seems more fair to re-enable
support for 10.10/10.11 and just swallow the error caused by the broken
SDK header (by turning it back into a warning in C++11 mode).

Fixes #46372.

Closes #50229.

FormulaInstaller: rescue tap unavail for reqs too

Calling `compute_dependencies` will make sure both requirements and
dependencies are expanded, so that any referenced taps can be
auto-tapped. Prior to this commit only dependencies were expanded for
the sake of auto-tapping, so dependencies of requirements would cause
installation to fail whenever a tap unavailable exception was
encountered.

This is a brilliant formula to get working in homebrew.

Note that this is VirtualBox OSE (Open Source Edition) which the project owners do _not_ distribute builds for, nor do they provide an update mechanism for it.

Virtualbox.org only distributes binaries under a 'Personal Use and Evaluation' license, which prohibits any commercial use. So being able to install the OSE version from homebrew is a big step forward.

Could you make a suggestion how to unify the two formulas gnupg and gnupg2?

I merged the two formulas in one, as you suggested.
The option to build the GnuPG 1 version is --gnupg1.
The commit is: michelSt/homebrew@15a78a4365612b56a7a8d18d75a9715777e8f141

As you can read hear: http://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gnupg-announce/2007q2/000254.html gnupg 1 is not binary compatible with gnupg 2:

> GnuPG-2 has a different architecture than GnuPG-1 (e.g. 1.4.7) in that
> it splits up functionality into several modules.  However, both
> versions may be installed alongside without any conflict.  In fact,
> the gpg version from GnuPG-1 is able to make use of the gpg-agent as
> included in GnuPG-2 and allows for seamless passphrase caching.  The
> advantage of GnuPG-1 is its smaller size and the lack of dependency on
> other modules at run and build time.  We will keep maintaining GnuPG-1
> versions because they are very useful for small systems and for server
> based applications requiring only OpenPGP support.

In fact as far as i know the pinentry-mac formula i have written (see: ticket #1068) to support a gui for entering the passphrase only works with gnupg 2.

Should we make one formula as in commit michelSt/homebrew@15a78a4365612b56a7a8d18d75a9715777e8f141, or a separate one like in commit michelSt/homebrew@bb6357b8a34b0252cbc4912560912bffe599f2d8 ?

You need --iconv flag whenever the files contain UTF-8 characters and are synchronized from OS/X HFS+ partition to a system with 'normal' UTF-8 filenames, i.e. to any system which is not OS/X: OS/X HFS+ UTF-8 filenames use 'UTF-8 decomposed' mode and are not compatible directly.

@wilkinson: Read this: http://progit.org/book/ A really good book.

One suggestion, always edit stuff in a separate branch:
`git checkout -b #NAME_OF_BRANCH#` Using the `-b`option changes directly to branch after it's created.

Push new branch:
`git push origin #NAME_OF_BRANCH#`

List branches:
`git branch -a`

Checkout branch:
`git checkout #NAME_OF_BRANCH#`

To keep up to date in the master branch:
`git checkout master && git fetch upstream && git merge upstream/master` _(upstream is the name of the remote server)_

I would suggest creating a branch. Which has a clean master as its ancestor.

E.g.: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/4521

Those merge messages can be omitted if your master is clean, and you have a separate branch with your changes. If you want to fast-forward a merge in your branch. All you need is use rebase. Which extracts your changes and applies them onto of the upstream changes.

This is because you have a dirty tree.

Easy fix:

`cd $(brew --prefix)`

`git branch -a` _(to make sure you are in the master branch)_

`git stage`

`brew update`

`git stage apply stage{0}` _(if you like to preserve your own changes)_

However, this means that it's watching for changes in those directories even when not actively installing anything. We should fix that imo. Will try to figure out how this mythical interactive shell works later on :)

Also, is there like a #homebrew irc channel? Or are you guys not on IRC? (which I could totally understand)

Actually, I already made it so the first time that it would only run whilst actually running "install-just-one". Max, was there a specific reason to move this to "install"? Because now it indeed keeps on running until the parents "install" is finished, so I feel strongly about wrapping "install-just-one"'s body again.

Firstly irc is freenode.net #machomebrew

I moved it to install because for efficiency reasons it seemed unecessary to start and stop the fsevents watcher multiple times. As, and correct me if wrong, the install-just-one is 99% of the install loop that the spill() function wraps.

I believe with the current argument, moving it to install-just-one wouldn't make a difference anyway as the interactive shell part is inside that block. So the results would be the same for both situations.

So in conclusion, in order to stop it watching when interactive shell is open we need more work anyway.

And my opinion: it's not worth it. I agree it sucks to drain CPU for nothing. But it's for a minority use case, and it's only a few percent for a small time. If we ever figure out an elegant solution it would be worth changing the code, but as it stands, we don't have one.

Although as I think more on it, the spill function should only surround the brew section anyway. We may want to move it into Formula.

However I should reiterate, this won't fix the problem above as the interactive shell is still further in (see brew.h.rb install())

Also to add more words to this issue (apologies!), really the fsvents loop has to surround the shell anyway, otherwise how could you be sure you haven't installed to somewhere you shouldn't be?

-              Apple API extensions are not visible in this environment,

-              or behave incorrectly if prototypes are not in scope or

What's the difference in how the two actually affect things at the moment?

None of the depends_on specifiers matter; they are all treated as "required" for purposes of installing a brew. They do serve as useful documentation and as  reminder to "implement this feature some day."

In fact, they will be useful to higher-level UIs build on top of brew, since those UIs can introspect on the dependencies and be smarter about asking the user which ones to use.

This is a stupid comment maybe, but i get this error now i try to "brew update": 

error: Untracked working tree file 'Library/Formula/rsnapshot.rb' would be overwritten by merge.  Aborting
Updating 941a900..c5a92af
 I guess i could just delete rsnapshot.rb, but i'd like to understand what happens. 

Thanks!

Chris

This is a git error message propagating up through brew's update command; "brew update" uses git underneath.

Basically, since you have an existing "rsnapshot.rb" brew, and this commit also adds a file w/ that name, git can't do an update for the reason it gives: it doesn't know whether to keep the existing file or blast it away with the new file.

If your existing brew matches what we merged, then deleting it locally is fine; otherwise you could move it to another path, update, then diff the files to see what's different.

As stated by the [formula cookbook](http://wiki.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/formula-cookbook) page in the wiki:

> The mxcl fork doesn’t dupe stuff that comes with OS X or stuff that is provided by RubyGems, CPAN or PyPi.

One of the rules that has been adopted for the main homebrew repository is not to package-manage things for which there is already a dedicated package manager.  The reasoning is that a python package manager, such as `pip` can do a much better job of providing accurate, up-to-date installations than `brew` can.

Of course the wonderful thing about homebrew is that you are totally free to disregard any of the rules, make your own brew that does whatever the heck it wants, and use github to share it with your friends if you like.

I doubt this brew would be re-accepted even if it was patched to actually build.  The reasoning behind removing it was sound:
-  TeXLive is a large, complex system.
-  Large, complex systems are a pain in the rear to compile and maintain when they inevitably break.
-  There is already a dedicated team that is shouldering the responsibility of dealing with that pain in the rear.

Given the above points, we decided to defer to MacTeX as it provides a high quality TeXLive installation and reduces the amount of bug fixing we need to do.

But than you have to remove several packages that can be found in homebrew. E.g. ack can be installed using CPAN. I love it to install ack using homebrew because I have no idea on how to do it with CPAN. I am a little bit worried that I have to learn tons of package managing system for my mac :( .

+  url 'http://msgpack.org/releases/cpp/msgpack-0.5.7.tar.gz'

   def install
+    fails_with_llvm "LLVM-GCC failed compiling with message: unpack.c:463: internal compiler error: Segmentation fault: 11"
review_comments.body: This doesn't go in the install section. It floats around with `options`, `patches`, `depends_on`, etc.
What's the reasoning behind this change?

`GitDownloadStrategy#initialize` fails if a name isn't passed to `Formula#initialize`, because it has a guard clause checking for `name == '__UNKNOWN__'`. The `CurlDownloadStrategy` doesn't have the same issue, which is why this worked perfectly fine until now.
Makes sense. Thanks!

Ahh. Never mind, seems `/System/Library/Extensions` is the **only** folder OS X will check during boot:

args = std_cmake_parameters.split

@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+require 'formula'
+
+class Zoltan < Formula
+  url 'http://trilinos.sandia.gov/download/files/trilinos-10.6.4-Source.tar.gz'
+  homepage 'http://www.cs.sandia.gov/Zoltan'
+  md5 '75b393e633bde4d9565df304f84b52e4'
+  version '3.3'
+
+  def options
+    [
+      ["--with-scotch", "Enable PT-Scotch support"],
+
+      # Zoltan does not support parmetis version 4 yet.
+      # ["--with-parmetis", "Enable Parmetis support"],
+    ]
+  end
+
+  depends_on 'cmake' => :build
+  depends_on 'scotch'   if ARGV.include? '--with-scotch'
+
+  # Zoltan does not support parmetis version 4 yet.
+  # depends_on 'parmetis' if ARGV.include? '--with-parmetis'
+
+  def install
+
+    mkdir 'zoltan-build'
+
+    args = ["-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=#{prefix}",
+            "-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release",
+            "-DTPL_ENABLE_MPI:BOOL=ON",
+            "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Fortran:BOOL=OFF",
+            "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
+            "-DTrilinos_VERBOSE_CONFIGURE:BOOL=OFF",
+            "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_ALL_PACKAGES:BOOL=OFF",
+            "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Zoltan:BOOL=ON",
+            "-DZoltan_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
+            "-DZoltan_ENABLE_TESTS:BOOL=OFF"
+            ]
review_comments.body:
Homebrew provides some baseline CMake arguments via the `std_cmake_parameters` method which returns:

```
"-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX='#{prefix}' -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=None -Wno-dev"
```

Setting `BUILD_TYPE` to `None` is important as it tells CMake to use our `CFLAGS` rather than creating it's own. This section should be re-written similar to:

``` ruby
args = std_cmake_parameters.split
args.concat [
  "-DTPL_ENABLE_MPI:BOOL=ON",   
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Fortran:BOOL=OFF", 
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DTrilinos_VERBOSE_CONFIGURE:BOOL=OFF",  
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_ALL_PACKAGES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Zoltan:BOOL=ON",   
  "-DZoltan_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DZoltan_ENABLE_TESTS:BOOL=OFF"
]
```

 require 'formula'
 
 class Mapserver < Formula
-  url 'http://download.osgeo.org/mapserver/mapserver-6.0.0.tar.gz'
+  url 'http://download.osgeo.org/mapserver/mapserver-6.0.1.tar.gz'
   homepage 'http://mapserver.org/'
-  md5 '5bcb1a6fb4a743e9f069466fbdf4ab76'
+  md5 'b96287449dcbca9a2fcea3a64905915a'
 
   depends_on 'gd'
   depends_on 'proj'
   depends_on 'gdal'
-  depends_on 'libagg'
 
-  def patches
-    # http://trac.osgeo.org/mapserver/ticket/3877 (patch from the 6.0 release branch)
-    { :p4 => "http://trac.osgeo.org/mapserver/changeset/11714?format=diff&new=11714" }
+  if ARGV.include? '--with-geos'
+    depends_on 'geos'
+  end
+
+  if ARGV.include? '--with-postgresql'
+    depends_on 'postgresql' unless MacOS.lion?
+  end
+
+  def options
+    [
+      ["--with-geos", "Build support for GEOS spatial operations"],
+      ["--with-php", "Build PHP MapScript module"],
+      ["--with-postgresql", "Build support for PostgreSQL as a data source"]
+    ]
+  end
+
+  def configure_args
+    args = [
+      "--prefix=#{prefix}",
+      "--with-proj",
+      "--with-gdal",
+      "--with-ogr",
+      "--with-png=/usr/X11"
+    ]
+
+    if ARGV.include? '--with-geos'
+      args.push "--with-geos"
+    end
+
+    if ARGV.include? '--with-php'
+      args.push "--with-php=/usr/include/php"
+    end
+
+    if ARGV.include? '--with-postgresql'
+      if MacOS.lion? # Lion ships with PostgreSQL libs
+        args.push "--with-postgis"
+      else
+        args.push "--with-postgis=#{Formula.factory('postgresql').prefix}/bin/pg_config"
review_comments.body:
Should just use:

``` ruby
"--with-postgis=#{HOMEBREW_PREFIX}/bin/pg_config"
```

Then a user can install passing `--ignore-dependencies` if they don't want the hassle of upgrading PostgreSQL and the formula build won't fail because the path to `pg_config` has the version number of something that is not installed.

@@ -0,0 +1,15 @@
+require 'formula'
+
+class Waxsim < Formula
+  url 'https://github.com/probablycorey/WaxSim/tarball/a694549be56f19095e6c342ed7867cd677df4137'
+  homepage 'https://github.com/probablycorey/WaxSim'

review_comments.body:
Homebrew has an `inreplace` function, so this could be e.g.

`inreplace 'WaxSim.xcodeproj/project.pbxproj', 'shellPath = /bin/sh', 'shellPath = /usr/bin/true'`

rather than using sed. Perhaps even

``` ruby
inreplace 'WaxSim.xcodeproj/project.pbxproj' do |s|
  s.change_make_var! 'shellPath', '/usr/bin/true'
end
```

though I don't know how well the block-style inreplace functions would cope with Xcode project files.

+    puts "Your build is #{bld}" if ARGV.verbose?
review_comments.body:
Well I lost a pretty cogent post there, but suffice it to say I ran 

```
find . -type f | xargs fgrep -F x86 --color
find . -type f | xargs fgrep -F 64 --color
find . -type f | xargs fgrep -F cpu --color
```

and found references to endian, libtool, and fill order.  My answer to what does it buy included something
along the lines:  If an accurate build c-v-o isn't detrimental, is it logical to be consistent?  My multi-line code
of many regrets is:

```
c = MacOS.prefer_64_bit? ? "x86_64" : "i386"
v = "-apple-"
o = MacOS.lion? ? "darwin11" : "darwin10"
o = "darwin9" if MacOS.leopard?
s = c+v+o
```

I'd could swap that in if there if there is consensus on how I should fix this.

review_comments.body: Thanks for your comment but that's the problem. At least on my brew install, ENV.cxx is g++4.2. review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@
+require 'formula'
+
+class Clhep < Formula
+  url 'http://proj-clhep.web.cern.ch/proj-clhep/DISTRIBUTION/tarFiles/clhep-2.1.1.0.tgz'
+  homepage 'http://proj-clhep.web.cern.ch/proj-clhep/'
+  md5 'f8acb50a9cdb9ac8937fecfcb741ba10'
+
+  def install
+    Dir.chdir 'CLHEP' do
+      #forcing CXX to be g++ the configure script will find CXX to be g++4.2
+      #and will screw up AR and all those
+      system "./configure",'CXX=g++', "--disable-debug", "--disable-dependency-tracking",
review_comments.body:
I would ask the CLHEP developers to remove the switch. If they won't, add a patch that does it.

Homebrew needs flexibility in which compiler gets used---for some versions of XCode `g++` points to LLVM-GCC and the only way to direct a formula to use vanilla GCC is by setting CXX to be `g++-4.2`. It is looking like Apple is going full steam ahead on Clang so it is possible that `g++` won't even be an option in the future for some systems.

Either way, we need to be able to control this variable.

review_comments.body:
Please tell me the other way. I could not find.
The 'shflags' uses gnu-getopt for  long option.
http://code.google.com/p/shflags/issues/detail?id=13

The formula can't link gnu-getopt at making install, because it's shell script functions.
It means that I can't use in the formula:
  ENV['GETOPT']=Formula.factory("gnu-getopt").bin+"getopt"

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,15 @@
+require 'formula'
+
+class Gocode < Formula
+  head 'https://github.com/nsf/gocode.git'
+  url 'https://github.com/nsf/gocode.git', :tag => 'compatible-with-go-release.r57'
+  homepage 'https://github.com/nsf/gocode'
+  
+  version 'r57'
review_comments.body:
gocode is pretty sensitive to being on the most recent go; the go compiler and gocode should be matched up. I suggest using this tag:

compatible-with-go-release.r60 which matches up with brew go which is at r60.1

given how tightly coupled gocode is to the version of the go compiler, I suggest that the go dependency is returned; otherwise you are going to get a bunch of people complaining about gocode not working.

ENV['PREFIX'] = prefix

+require 'formula'

+class Nagios < Formula
+  url 'http://downloads.sourceforge.net/project/nagios/nagios-3.x/nagios-3.2.3/nagios-3.2.3.tar.gz'
+  homepage 'http://www.nagios.org/'
+  md5 'fe1be46e6976a52acdb021a782b5d04b'
+
+  depends_on 'gd'
+  depends_on 'nagios-plugins'
+
+  def nagios_sbin;  prefix+'cgi-bin'; end
+  def nagios_etc;   etc+'nagios';     end
+  def nagios_var;   var+'lib/nagios'; end
+  def htdocs;       share+'htdocs';   end
+  def user;         `id -un`.chomp;   end
+  def group;        `id -gn`.chomp;   end
+
+  def install
+    ENV.x11 # Required to compile some CGI's against the build-in libpng.
+    system "./configure", "--disable-debug",
+                          "--disable-dependency-tracking",
+                          "--prefix=#{prefix}",
+                          "--sbindir=#{nagios_sbin}",
+                          "--sysconfdir=#{nagios_etc}",
+                          "--localstatedir=#{nagios_var}",
+                          "--datadir=#{htdocs}",
+                          "--with-cgiurl=/nagios/cgi-bin",
+                          "--with-htmurl=/nagios",
+                          "--with-nagios-user=#{user}",
+                          "--with-nagios-group=#{group}",
+                          "--with-command-user=#{user}",
+                          "--with-command-group=_www",
+                          "--with-httpd-conf=#{share}"
+    system "make all"
+    system "make install"
+
+    # Install config
+    system "make install-config"
+    system "make install-webconf"
+    (share+'org.nagios.plist').write startup_plist
+
+    # Symlink plugins
+    libexec.rmdir
+    ln_s '/usr/local/sbin/nagios-plugins', libexec
+  end
+
+  def startup_plist
+    <<-EOS.undent
+    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+    <!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
+    <plist version="1.0">
+    <dict>
+            <key>KeepAlive</key>
+            <true/>
+            <key>Label</key>
+            <string>org.nagios</string>
+            <key>ProgramArguments</key>
+            <array>
+                    <string>/usr/local/bin/nagios</string>
+                    <string>#{nagios_etc}/nagios.cfg</string>
+            </array>
+            <key>RunAtLoad</key>
+            <true/>
+            <key>StandardErrorPath</key>
+            <string>/dev/null</string>
+            <key>StandardOutPath</key>
+            <string>/dev/null</string>
+            <key>UserName</key>
+            <string>#{user}</string>
+    </dict>
+    </plist>
+    EOS
+  end
+
+  def caveats
+    <<-EOS.undent
+    First we need to create a command dir using superhuman powers:
+
+      $ mkdir -p #{nagios_var}/rw
+      $ sudo chgrp _www #{nagios_var}/rw
+      $ sudo chmod 2775 #{nagios_var}/rw
+
+    Then install the Nagios web frontend into Apple's build-in Apache:
+
+      1) Turn on Personal Web Sharing.
+
+      2) Load the php module by patching /etc/apache2/httpd.conf:
+
+        -#LoadModule php5_module        libexec/apache2/libphp5.so
+        +LoadModule php5_module        libexec/apache2/libphp5.so
+
+      3) Symlink the sample config and create your web account:
+
+        $ sudo ln -s #{share}/nagios.conf /etc/apache2/other/
review_comments.body: We try avoid prefixing commands with '$' to make copy/paste easier.

+require 'formula'

+                          "--sysconfdir=#{nagios_etc}",
+                          "--localstatedir=#{nagios_var}",

+                          "--with-nagios-user=#{user}",
+                          "--with-nagios-group=#{group}",
+                          "--with-command-user=#{user}",
+                          "--with-command-group=_www",
+                          "--with-httpd-conf=#{share}"
+    system "make all"
+    system "make install"
+
+    # Install config
+    system "make install-config"
+    system "make install-webconf"
+    (share+'org.nagios.plist').write startup_plist
+
+    # Symlink plugins
+    libexec.rmdir
+    ln_s '/usr/local/sbin/nagios-plugins', libexec
+  end
+
+  def startup_plist
+    <<-EOS.undent
+    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+    <!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
+    <plist version="1.0">
+    <dict>
+            <key>KeepAlive</key>
+            <true/>
+            <key>Label</key>
+            <string>org.nagios</string>
+            <key>ProgramArguments</key>
+            <array>
+                    <string>/usr/local/bin/nagios</string>
+                    <string>#{nagios_etc}/nagios.cfg</string>
+            </array>
+            <key>RunAtLoad</key>
+            <true/>
+            <key>StandardErrorPath</key>
+            <string>/dev/null</string>
+            <key>StandardOutPath</key>
+            <string>/dev/null</string>
+            <key>UserName</key>
+            <string>#{user}</string>
+    </dict>
+    </plist>
+    EOS
+  end
+
+  def caveats
+    <<-EOS.undent
+    First we need to create a command dir using superhuman powers:
+
+      mkdir -p #{nagios_var}/rw
+      sudo chgrp _www #{nagios_var}/rw
+      sudo chmod 2775 #{nagios_var}/rw
+
+    Then install the Nagios web frontend into Apple's build-in Apache:
+
+      1) Turn on Personal Web Sharing.
+
+      2) Load the php module by patching /etc/apache2/httpd.conf:
+
+        -#LoadModule php5_module        libexec/apache2/libphp5.so
+        +LoadModule php5_module        libexec/apache2/libphp5.so
+
+      3) Symlink the sample config and create your web account:
+
+        sudo ln -s #{share}/nagios.conf /etc/apache2/other/
+        htpasswd -cs #{nagios_etc}/htpasswd.users nagiosadmin
+        sudo apachectl restart
+
+    If you want to run nagios automatically at startup:
+
+      sudo cp #{share}/org.nagios.plist /Library/LaunchDaemons/
+      sudo launchctl load -w /Library/LaunchDaemons/org.nagios.plist
+
+    ...or simply run it on demand:
+
+      nagios /usr/local/etc/nagios/nagios.cfg
review_comments.body: `#{etc}/nagios/nagios.cfg`

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -234,6 +239,25 @@ class FormulaInstaller
       @show_summary_heading = true
     end
   end
+
+  private
+
+  # This method gives us a chance to pre-process command line arguments before the
+  # installer forks and `Formula.install` kicks in.
+  def filtered_args
+    # Did the user actually pass the formula this installer is considering on
+    # the command line?
+    def explicitly_requested?; ARGV.formulae.include? f end
+    previous_install = Tab.for_formula f
+
+    args = ARGV.clone
+    args.concat previous_install.used_options
+    args.uniq! # Just in case some dupes were added
+
+    args.delete_at args.index '--HEAD' if args.build_head? and not explicitly_requested?
review_comments.body:
could be clearer IMO:

```
args.delete '--HEAD' if args.build_head? and not explicitly_requested?
```

Technically it removes all '--HEAD' but as you made it uniq just before it will not change a thing.
It is a bit less efficient (average is n compared to n/2 elements comparisons), but not relevant here.
